title: Cash Buyers Decline Across Majority of U.K. Cities
text:
In 90% of cities across the U.K., the number of cash buyers has declined since 2016, according to a report released Friday in the U.K. from Zoopla.



The exodus—which Zoopla chalked up to a result of 2016’s stamp duty tax changes and its impact on investors and second home-owners—has compounded the slowdown in price growth across the 20 cities the online real estate portal analyzed.

Stamp duty is the tax paid on the purchase of a residential property in England priced at more than £125,000 (US$154,031).



The tax rate increases in hand with the sale price and, as of 2016, is subject to a 3% surcharge if the property is a second home or buy-to-let residence. First-time buyers are exempt from paying stamp duty if their purchase costs less than £500,000.



The number of cash buyers has declined most significantly in cities with the highest capital values and lowest yields, the report said, mainly encompassing London and surrounding southern cities.



The number of cash buyers dropped most in Cambridge, down 30% since 2016, followed by London and Oxford.



Only Aberdeen and Liverpool saw a rise in cash buyers since 2016.

“A change in the mix of buyers has impacted the demand for housing across cities since 2016,” Richard Donnell, research and insight director at Zoopla, said in the report. “The reduction in cash buyers has been marked in southern cities and we believe this is down to a decline in investment-buying across high value cities. This has compounded the slowdown in price rises, which we see as a return to a more sustainable pace of price growth rather than an impending re-correction.”

In contrast, demand from mortgaged home-owners appears resilient, supported by low mortgage rates and high levels of employment, Mr. Donnell said.



The average property price across the 20 U.K. cities Zoopla analyzed stood at £257,900 in August, a 1.9% rise from a year ago.



Growth was highest in Leicester, in the East Midlands, where values are 4.8% higher than they were last year. Liverpool, in North West England, followed, where property prices rose 4.6% in the same time.
